metadata.case_name: Holders of pre-settlement minor inams v. State of Orissa
metadata.case_number: Civil Appeals Nos. 474 to 501, 503 to 505, 508 to 512, 514 and 515 of 1959

facts.text: Appellants are holders of pre-settlement minor inams in the State of Orissa. Their grants are different in regard to the time when they were made and the lands involved.
Grants were made for performance of services of deities and were classed as Devadayam grants in the revenue papers.
Grants comprised certain lands (not whole villages), hence classified as minor inams, and included both melwaram and kudiwaram rights.
Orissa High Court by judgment and orders dated November 28, 1956 (and December 4, 1956) dismissed 42 petitions under Art. 226 filed by appellants and others.
High Court certified cases fit for appeal to Supreme Court under Art. 132.
Notification No.4971-XV-9154-E.A. dated July 15, 1955 issued by Orissa State Government.
Orissa Estates Abolition Act, 1951 (Act 1 of 1952): Bill introduced January 17, 1950, passed by Legislative Assembly September 28, 1951, reserved for President, assented January 23, 1952.
Amending Act: Orissa Estates Abolition Amendment Act, 1954 (Act XXVII of 1954), reserved for President and assented to.
Original Act abolished all estates of intermediaries; on notification by Government, estates vested in Government.
Amending Act widened definition of 'estate' to cover minor inams.
Constitution First Amendment Act, 1951 enacted June 18, 1951, inserting Art. 31A with retrospective operation.

legal_issues.text: Whether Notification No.4971-XV-9154-E.A. dated July 15, 1955, issued by the Orissa State Government, and the Orissa Estates Abolition Act, 1951 as amended by the Orissa Estates Abolition Amendment Act, 1954 were respectively beyond the competence of the State and the Orissa State Legislature.
Whether the amending Act of 1954 is protected by Art. 31A, as it amends a previous law by enlarging the definition of estate rather than itself providing for compulsory acquisition.
Whether the word 'estate' as defined in s.2(g) before amendment applied to pre-settlement minor inams of lands, or only to an inam estate meaning whole inam villages per Madras Estates Land Act.

petitioner_arguments.text: Original Act and amending Act were, jointly or severally, beyond the competence of the State Legislature and the notification was void.
Benefit of Art. 31A available to original Act but not to amending Act, which was not a law providing for compulsory acquisition but only amended previous law by enlarging definition of estate.

Word 'estate' in s.2(g) before amendment did not apply to pre-settlement minor inams of lands as it applied only to an inam estate, meaning whole inam villages per definition in Madras Estates Land Act, 1908.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: s.2(g) and s.2(q) Orissa Estates Abolition Act, 1951; s.3(2)(d) Madras Estates Land Act, 1908

petitioner_arguments.text: Ejusdem generis rule applies to definition of 'estate' in Art. 31A(2)(a) and corresponding new definition in Abolition Act.

court_reasoning.text: First argument untenable: Amending Act must be considered in relation to original Act it amends; President's assent to amending Act brings protection of Art. 31A as it extends provisions for compulsory acquisition to new properties.
court_reasoning.key_observation: President assented to extension of law for compulsory acquisition of new categories of property.

court_reasoning.text: Argument that minor inams not estates lacking substance: They are inams; Constitution's Art. 31A defines 'estate' to include any inam; amending Act follows that; excludes resort to s.2(q) or Madras Act definition.
court_reasoning.key_observation: New definition of 'estate' sufficiently wide to cover minor inams.

court_reasoning.text: Ejusdem generis rule not applicable to 'inam' in Art. 31A(2)(a); applies perhaps to 'other similar grant' but not to specific 'inam'; inams of any kind included, whether lands or whole villages.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Once inams included, distinction on size or rights irrelevant.

court_reasoning.text: s.3(1) of Abolition Act: Government notification vests estate in State; if definition covers minor inam and notification issued, consequences follow; law not challengeable if assented by President.

holdings.text: Amending Act protected by Art. 31A; assent of President to amending Act brings in protection as it extends original law to new properties.
Definition of 'estate' in amending Act covers pre-settlement minor inams; no need to refer to s.2(q) or Madras Act.
Notification valid; minor inams vest in State free from encumbrances upon notification.

statutes_cited.name: Orissa Estates Abolition Act, 1951 (Act 1 of 1952)
statutes_cited.relevance: Abolishes estates; definition of 'estate' widened by amendment to include minor inams; vesting upon notification.

statutes_cited.name: Orissa Estates Abolition Amendment Act, 1954 (Act XXVII of 1954)
statutes_cited.relevance: Widens definition of 'estate' to include minor inams; clarifies no removal from old ambit.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Art. 31A protects laws for acquisition of estates if assented by President; 'estate' includes inam.

statutes_cited.name: Madras Estates Land Act, 1908
statutes_cited.relevance: Definition of 'estate' as whole inam village; not applicable due to wider definition in Abolition Act and Constitution.

outcome.summary: Supreme Court upholds Orissa High Court's dismissal of writ petitions; holds Orissa Estates Abolition Act, 1951 as amended, and the notification valid and within competence; minor inams vest in State.

key_quotes.text: The amending Act must be considered in relation to the old law which it sought to extend and the President assented to such an extension or, in other words, to a law for the compulsory acquisition of property for public purposes.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Explains why amending Act gets Art. 31A protection.

key_quotes.text: The extended definition in the Constitution and a similar extended definition in the Act thus exclude resort to the general definition clause in s.2(q) of the Abolition Act and the definition of estate in the Madras Estates Land Act.
key_quotes.speaker: court
